elements.2211.03186_346cca8a08fafc8a8a4668981e52f: * Large pretrained, zero-shot capable models have shown considerable success both for standard transfer tasks, but recently also as a starting point for Continual Learning.
elements.2211.03186_0940ca9c46d4bb98781b541042c3a: * However, these zero-shot models lose their benefits and robustness towards distribution shifts through naive finetuning. * Continual Learning, where a consistent distribution shift is encountered, is there a tough task for standard zero-shot models. * In this work, we showcase that where simple finetuning falls short, simple momentum-based weight interpolation can provide consistent improvements for Continual Learning tasks, for both memory-free and memory-based methods. * We highlight that simple finetuning, and out-of-the-box zero-shot transfer performance, while easily outperforming existing methods not reliant on pretraining, can be improved significantly through continual learning with momentum-averaging. * With the right adaptation, we find that momentum-based adaptation allows the continual learner to inch in parts very close to the joint training limits.
elements.2211.03186_83105eb9d1444476c7650868d5e50: * Quick introduction to Continual Learning * Quick introduction to large pretrained models and strong zero-shot transfer. * Hint to pretraining used in continual learning. * Important: Hint that we ablate over smaller learning rates, so it is not just plain effective LR reduction.
elements.2211.03186_54b494323b82edc0346e2b66e6be8: augment the loss function with a regularization term that is intended to prevent forgetting by keeping the current parameters close to the parameters obtained during the past tasks
elements.2211.03186_ca08a86d480e4578f26ade511a268: performs Laplace approximation on the posterior probabilities of the parameters of all previous task and uses the obtained means and covariance matrices to keep the current parameters close to the parameters of the previous tasks via the Mahalanobis distance
elements.2211.03186_2d73ea017adebefa5daf1d33a3e95: suggests merely computing a momentum average of a single covariance matrix, and only keeping the parameters from the end of the previous task
elements.2211.03186_72364b6eec332ef557ec386a619ac: also keeps the model parameters from the previous task and as a regularizer adds the cross-entropy between the class logits computed with the old weights and those with the current weights, using only data from the current task
elements.2211.03186_1564737c18f56e863681590bea864: shows that using dropout as a regularizer forces the model to learn a gating mechanism such that for different tasks, different paths of the network are active.
elements.2211.03186_1c9c8fce6da0949b2f183fe546923: by storing a small subset of the training data into a buffer, and continually replaying it as the model moves on to learn new tasks.
elements.2211.03186_3a99f228567b26ac8ee2c57b2ee30: introduces regularization in the rehearsal scheme by matching the logits of the past with the logits computed by the current network parameters
elements.2211.03186_3be81750eeae3767a4fc81135392c: enforce optimization constraints in the current task using data from past tasks
elements.2211.03186_72055bbb2f0181b44942d6dbdfd4f: greedily stores samples in memory, and only trains the model at test time using merely samples from the buffer
elements.2211.03186_3d6077b809de304147abbbb045785: uses a slow network for learning general task-agnostic features through Self-Supervised Learning, and a slow network for learning task-specific features for the problem at hand
elements.2211.03186_96e6f3bd56a189c42e4dc5e44f682: learns contrastive general task-agnostic features, and only at test time trains a linear classifier using data from the buffer.
elements.2211.03186_cdd868150b97fce34e428eb983363: aim to locate and operate in flat minima regions for each task sequentially, thereby retaining performance on the old tasks
elements.2211.03186_d48242f884d978e446d90d6b74956: proposes to independently add small random noise multiple times to the parameters in the pre-training procedure, thereby obtaining similar but different loss functions which are optimized together in order to locate flat minima.
elements.2211.03186_b2b28a95791984eceed23bb44dd93: studies how batch size, dropout and learning rate decay affect the model's ability to locate flat minima
elements.2211.03186_0c0a510605f0261bd8e65b40d333d: introduces the use of the Sharpness-Aware Minimization (SAM)
elements.2211.03186_155f242c1d39cf1aba48bb06f5a76: procedure in continual learning, which explicitly optimizes for parameters lying in flat basins
elements.2211.03186_c2a4c96be1c156706b9911c3288d9: demonstrates that averaging the weights of the model during training will implicitly land the final optimum in a flat region
elements.2211.03186_ab6238afdf5d56edbc581f47ed779: Compared to the other flatness related approaches, SWA is only evaluated when the data stream is considered independent and identically distributed (IID)
elements.2211.03186_9ff98f24cda4e413a2f677a0d0e6a: Given the aforementioned benefits of locating flat optima in a lifelong learning scenario, we aim to show that this approach can also substantially improve the performance when models are trained continually
elements.2211.03186_4ea93615e0f8f6ab03210b628407a: Nonetheless, this is an orthogonal method to not only all other categories of continual learning approaches, but also to the other flatness-seeking methods; for example
elements.2211.03186_ecf786b103486a5b1ff3cd569f229: demonstrates the benefits of combining both SAM and SWA when training on an IID stream of data.
elements.2211.03186_d075470f72471bc75a07cccf3522e: In this section we first cover the necessary preliminaries regarding a general Continual Learning (CL) problem, followed by an overview of our proposed method.
elements.2211.03186_7b165a8017e8c0fde050cd33a1e78: The main goal of Continual Learning is to train a model
elements.2211.03186_f53ef6813c54ccd0680b36524884e: tasks, such that for each task
elements.2211.03186_0c77de31bd6d2a3824e449846b71a: the learner gets access to a set of samples
elements.2211.03186_02680d574fb4a76d9f5253ad55a34: Formally, we solve the following optimization problem:
elements.2211.03186_2d416679432d17f823cbeb9e17141: The difficulty comes from the imposed characteristic that at the time of learning task
elements.2211.03186_52da1ca5ce69884a55f4dbc586afe: , the model has no access to data from previous tasks
elements.2211.03186_80a0d870e571cfe763a593c40ce30: , therefore disregarding the typical IID (independent and identically distributed) assumption about the data
elements.2211.03186_60448f75478117c1717badc2cdc9e: Memory-based approaches impose a slight relaxation on this property, by allowing the model to store a small buffer of samples.
elements.2211.03186_cc7ea17234f807e018f664b4165bf: demonstrated that fine-tuning a pre-trained model by retaining a running average of the weights leads to wider optima and better generalization performance
elements.2211.03186_e9b5baa83f7f96def9802d5413870: Nevertheless, this work has primarily focused on the context of IID data, and hasn't yet explored the capabilities of the approach when applied to a non-IID stream of data, such as the one typically seen in Continual Learning.
elements.2211.03186_89c8bccad34ab82129f8b111ffc9a: in the Continual Learning literature have focused on the benefits of optimizing for flat minima, we aim to explore whether the implicit flat-finding minima procedure of SWA is beneficial for life-long learning.
elements.2211.03186_e6078f6c4a732755310057bd2c4d0: To this end we introduce a reformulation of SWA named
elements.2211.03186_e5bdde26e770b785e577884772c98: , with the goal of estimating how well a model performs in a continual learning setting when keeping an exponential moving average of the weights
elements.2211.03186_1fee355bbdf1cc7748fa9300e4748: A simplified version of the MCL procedure is summarized in Algorithm
elements.2211.03186_f8497d931a9af0daa38f3db4d707b: Note that MCL doesn't resemble a typical continual learning method, which commonly incorporates a memory buffer, a loss regularization, and/or dependency on explicit task boundaries
elements.2211.03186_6561c3f4910f3d0ff5e8ef752a293: This approach can be neatly packed into an optimizer, and in fact be used orthogonal to any of the existing continual learning methods.
elements.2211.03186_b8cb35ca25d6b22ef06ea72147060: On a more abstract level, our approach also builds upon the Complimentary Learning Systems (CLS)
elements.2211.03186_c2924b851378070beed3da8694b3d: theory from neuroscience, which essentially states that humans are capable of learning continually with the help of two complimentary systems: A
elements.2211.03186_60921471315c42abbc7e357193799: learning system, which allows for rapidly learning new experiences via synaptic changes in the hippocamal system; and a
elements.2211.03186_ace01f0564e7aaa509c5878330266: learning system which gradually integrates these new experiences in the ensemble of past observations stored in the neocortical memory system.
elements.2211.03186_b05ac084954edecfbc1c543f2e79f: This section provides details regarding the evaluation protocol (Section
elements.2211.03186_f43f6139591adbce9c4799179969d: ), followed by an analysis of the obtained experimental results (Section
elements.2211.03186_3f6618ae65f46d352bbfbbcfcbdb5: ), concluded by an ablation study of the hyperparameters (Section
elements.2211.03186_45844c77b55c48b425368730041a3: For the purpose of evaluating the proposed method, we provide benchmarks on three datasets commonly used in the continual learning literature: CIFAR-10
elements.2211.03186_c1fb5e1ba914b8d1205b362e1939f: In order to train and evaluate the methods in a continual manner, we split each dataset in several tasks, in a way that each sequential task contains non-overlapping classes
elements.2211.03186_dc25eb22c408e59634f1a9530c0ed: More precisely, Seq-CIFAR-10 consists of 5 tasks (each containing 2 classes), Seq-CIFAR-100 consists of 10 tasks (each containing 10 classes), and Seq-Tiny-ImageNet consists of 10 tasks (each containing 20 classes).
elements.2211.03186_38eb6691443d737087adfb446f4a9: We consider two standard continual frameworks of evaluation: Task Incremental Learning (Task-IL) and Class Incremental Learning (Class-IL)
elements.2211.03186_0caa419d99a38843013344a61f87f: The main difference is that the former provides task identities at prediction time, meaning that the model only has to choose between the classes for the given task; whereas in the latter case the model is free to make predictions for classes outside the current task, thereby being much more susceptible to making mistakes.
elements.2211.03186_b4eb67fb4a3e55f3afdd7470b2c79: For all three datasets (CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, Tiny ImageNet), we fine-tune the pre-trained architecture of CLIP
elements.2211.03186_0632816531346657beb24d19ada5d: which uses ViT-B/16 as the image processing network.
elements.2211.03186_5f14c9d72f031294c85a5408bc799: In order to minimize the potential factors of variation, for all methods and all datasets we use the standard SGD
elements.2211.03186_63ffb7ea5975d8a8a4d645b67e149: optimizer with a fixed learning rate and no scheduler, as well as a fixed number of epochs set to
elements.2211.03186_d871d5d586fdd19d54e1ec6c04c70: Before evaluating on the test set, we perform a grid search on a hold-out validation set, which is obtained by randomly sampling
elements.2211.03186_b3fca47489bd622d560001bdde392: More precisely, we search for the best learning rate among the set
elements.2211.03186_73e7a8e743eb0c04ebc2369808834: We build our method on top of the implementation open-sourced by
elements.2211.03186_74d3b29481f3227ab0b6ff168021d: , where the authors implement a large variety of Continual Learning methods and benchmarks in PyTorch
elements.2211.03186_86cf36a64280e9624ab1c62c2775a: We compare the use of Momentum in three standard continual learning categories: fine-tuning (pure SGD
elements.2211.03186_0c3cf6358d12ca2d1ffd37a659cfe: All results presented below are obtained by averaging the runs over three seeds, where the standard deviation is provided as confidence bound.

elements.2211.03186_ba42e68e3f2c5f35b889ef68c743f: It should be noted that since the joint training is evaluated without providing task boundaries, the Task-IL scenario might actually outperform this upper bound.
elements.2211.03186_42d247745604826c5304aeccb7afd: The results of evaluating the methods in a Continual Learning scenario are summarized in Table
elements.2211.03186_fc410efa53d84b23173177cfbea8d: We empirically show that keeping a momentum-updated version of the network trained with either of the three prototypical methods (pure SGD, regularization-based, and rehearsal-based) results in consistent improvement over the baseline
elements.2211.03186_5d2c0f82e6aa59a3f4cfa2b2eed75: We argue that this is due to the ability of the momentum network to converge to flatter minima, thereby displaying better generalization performance on both old and new tasks.
elements.2211.03186_90ef5fa779c7ef19e9c268a01ef06: We hypothesize that the improvements on Seq-CIFAR-10 are marginal because this is a fairly easy continual learning benchmark by today's standards (5 tasks, with 2 classes each), and thereby there is not much room for improvement over the baselines
elements.2211.03186_4082e86a33293f8d86e35eab95e82: Nevertheless, as we move towards harder datasets with increased class diversity and longer task sequences, such as those in Seq-CIFAR-100 and Seq-Tiny-ImageNet, the gap between between using momentum or not significantly increases.
elements.2211.03186_43e2d0960735ac10484abbb1998ca: Interestingly, we observe that momentum based DER++ with a buffer size of 500 almost closes the gap in performance compared to the non-momentum based DER++ with buffer size 5000
elements.2211.03186_2ef6615518a04adf296d42666cf6d: Following are the aforementioned gaps for the Class-IL scenario, with the difference for the non-momentum based DER++ with buffer size of 500 denoted in parentheses:

elements.2211.03186_1fcad00d9bc5b5f937820c9a2bdd7: Again, the empirical results clearly indicate that keeping a running average copy of the network is beneficial across a variety of benchmarks, and helps further close the gap to the upper bound performance.
